content.question: Let <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function given by <math alttext="g of x, equals, the square root of 1 plus, cosine x, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following statements could be false on the interval <math alttext="pi over 2, is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 7 pi over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math> ?

choices.label: By the Extreme Value Theorem, there is a value <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that <math alttext="g of c, is less than or equal to, g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="pi over 2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 7 pi over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

By the Extreme Value Theorem, there is a value <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that <math alttext="g of c, is greater than or equal to, g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≥</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="pi over 2 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 7 pi over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

By the Intermediate Value Theorem, there is a value <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that <math alttext="g of c, equals, the fraction with numerator g of open parenthesis, pi over 2, close parenthesis, plus, g of open parenthesis, 7 pi over 4, close parenthesis, and denominator 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

By the Mean Value Theorem, there is a value <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that <math alttext="g prime of c, equals, the fraction with numerator g of open parenthesis, 7 pi over 4, close parenthesis, minus, g of open parenthesis, pi over 2, close parenthesis, and denominator 7 pi over 4, minus, pi over 2, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: By the Mean Value Theorem, there is a value <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that <math alttext="g prime of c, equals, the fraction with numerator g of open parenthesis, 7 pi over 4, close parenthesis, minus, g of open parenthesis, pi over 2, close parenthesis, and denominator 7 pi over 4, minus, pi over 2, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 5.2: Extreme Value Theorem, Global Versus Local Extrema, and Critical Points

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
